title: Postscript fonts
content:
Hi all,

This is my first forum post here and I’ve allready got a question.  
I know in previous school there was something told me about some designers who played with the postscript fonts. My tutor was talking about the fact that every letter changes, none was the same. I really can’t find anything in the library and on the internet about the designers who have done this. Please can you help me?

I’m currently doing my ISTD assingment and I’m looking at graffiti right now. (maybe any suggestions about that?)

Thank you all!

(excuse me for my poor English, I’m actually Dutch) ;)

Thanks!

 [‹ We want fractions!](http://web.archive.org/web/20080125221515/http:/typophile.com/node/41078 "Go to previous forum topic") [New Interest on Typography ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080125221515/http:/typophile.com/node/41157 "Go to next forum topic")
author: skruge

comments.content: I think the pioneers in random type are/were [Just van Rossum and Erik van Blokland](http://web.archive.org/web/20080125221515/http:/www.letterror.com/). Beowolf is the typeface that had a randomizer built in.
